text: Chris here is young he's what's hot he's
what's new and he's going to be doing
tonight's review whether you like it or
not hello my needle drops I'm Chris
Capello and it's time for an album
review today's review sons the
engine-room sons is a Fairfield
Connecticut based four-piece band that
have been kicking around the indie rock
circuit here in Connecticut and the
neighboring states for the past few
years they the three original members
were also members of a band called
Midian the modern dance which is one of
my favorite local bands and they are
sort of on a hiatus right now but
they're really great and so this sons
record is sort of tiding me over
basically until whatever happens with
with MIDI and the modern dance next but
anyway this uh this record comes on the
heels of their 2011 EP be good boy and a
demo that they put put out the previous
year which just add three tracks on it
but this is their first full-length LP
the engine room so this record finds the
band branching out from there indie rock
origins into something a little more
experimental and a little more hard
edged they take a lot from 90s emo bands
like sunny day real estate and mineral
and also some elements from slow core
and even math rock on this release the
van mixes a lot of styles that should be
familiar to any fans of 90s indie rock
but they do it in such a way that keeps
things constantly interesting and
engaging and has a kind of experimental
bent to it for me the real strength of
this album lies in the instrumental
backbone they the band was recently
joined by a new guitarist Peter cats who
is known for being the guitarist from
the Massachusetts post-rock math rock
band fugue who dis abandoned recently
prior to him joining sons and his
influence really shines all over this
record
you know he adds a lot of interesting
chord progressions guitar riffs you know
just elements that wouldn't necessarily
be present in a typical indie rock
record and it gives it this kind of
progressive feeling to it as a whole
cats seems to have this ability as a
guitar player to balance out the other
elements of the band he keeps the
rawness in check and also adds you know
aggression and noisy dissonant riffs
when he needs to and so it adds another
element to the sort of power trio sound
that they had before and makes it a much
more sort of engaging released it's
really interesting to listen to the band
you know write these really breakneck
speed songs he's aggressive tracks and
then go into more slow contemplative and
minimalist songs you know you get tracks
like the opening song repulse which is
this very slow kind of page or the lion
influence track and then you have songs
like lover lover and I could have made
time which are just these raw angry
dissonant emo songs I mean really you
know raw lyrics aggressive wrist this is
intense riff in in lover lover that um
it's like a harmonic balance between the
two guitarists from the band and they
just play so fast and with such
intensity that it kind of sends chills
down my spine but the best tracks on
this record come when the band balances
these two elements and combines them
into the same song the highlight track
for me is definitely crocodile the
second song in the album it starts with
this kind of soothing you know ethereal
guitar riff and these you know airy
vocals coming in seemingly from nowhere
but then builds up to this dramatic
climax before completely dropping off
towards the toward the end of the song
into this kind of modest mouse circa the
lonesome crowded West irri instrumental
part but then it all builds up back
again into this angry dissonant mix of
feedback and turns into kind of a
cursive style song I mean we'll rutledge
the frontman is just like shouting and
screaming over these bursts of guitar
feedback it's one of the most chilling
and fascinating for me moments of any
song from 2012 as far as I'm concerned
they have a similar thing going on the
title track the engine room it starts
out kind of slow and no sad but builds
up into this really anthemic chorus that
reminds me of their earlier work the
lyrics occasionally veer into you know
teenaged conor oberst territory but on
the whole I think that will Rutledge's
lyrics are more developed and more
poetic and have more you know lyrical
merit than his previous work and so it's
easier for me to appreciate them you
know even though I can totally identify
with what he's going for you know when
he's at his most literal it's nice to
have the sort of poetic elements you
know this is symbolism his use of
imagery to balance that and to keep
things you know mature I mean as a
teenager myself you know I feel
justified in listening to this record
because I've had you know all of the
feelings that he's yelling and singing
sadly about but I could see how someone
might be sort of turned off by them
anyway I'm feeling a strong 72 a light
eight on this one I thought it was great
but what did you think did you love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next son's the engine room
forever
